application. However, the city may, in its sole discretion, refund the entire
application fee if deemed appropriate under the circumstances. (Ord. 05-14, 4-
6-2005)
5.08.070: APPLICATION INVESTIGATION:
Upon receipt of an application for a license or permit, where ordinances of the
city require an inspection or investigation before the issuance of such permit
or license, the license official or his authorized representative or such other
agency, including the police department and the planning and zoning department
as these ordinances specifically empower, shall make such investigation within
five (5) business days after the time the application was received by the
agency or department. However, when adequate investigation requires
correspondence with agencies or other sources of information outside the city,
or the license applicant is not ready to be inspected, such investigation shall
be completed within fifteen (15) business days. The officer charged with the
duty of making the investigation or inspection shall make a report thereon,
favorable or otherwise, within five (5) business days after making the
investigation or inspection. The Salt Lake Valley health department shall, for
the protection of health, make or cause to be made, an inspection in regard to
licenses in connection with the care and handling of food, the prevention of
nuisances and the spread of disease. The fire department shall make or cause to
be made inspections relating to the safety of buildings or other structures
licensed hereunder. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.08.080: ADDITIONAL INVESTIGATIONS:
As soon as practical, the license official, in his discretion, may refer the
application for additional investigation to the fire department, police
department or other official or body for the purpose of investigation and
inspection concerning the general reputation of the licensee, whether the
business is or has been conducted in a lawful, quiet, orderly and helpful
manner, and the conditions of health and safety of such premises, together with
any other fact or facts that the city should know in acting upon the
application. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.08.090: REPORT OF INVESTIGATIONS:
Upon being requested to do so by the mayor or the license official, the police
department, fire department, or any other official or department so requested
shall conduct the investigation and inspection provided for in this chapter and
submit to the mayor or license official a report on such investigation and
inspection, together with recommendations as to whether the license should be
granted or denied. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.08.100: ACTION BY MAYOR:
After receipt of the referenced reports and recommendations of the license
official, police department, fire department or other official or body, the
mayor shall act upon the application as he deems just and proper in regard to
granting or denying the same, and may order further information or
investigation if such appears necessary. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.08.110: COMPLIANCE WITH BUILDING AND LAND USE REQUIREMENTS:
No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business, and no permit shall
be issued if the premises and building use do not fully comply with the city's
building and land use ordinances. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005; amd. Ord. 12-15, 7-11-
2012)
5.08.120: APPLICATION APPROVAL:
In the event the city approves a business license, the business license shall
be signed by the mayor or impressed by his facsimile, and forwarded to the
applicant. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.08.130: DENIAL CONDITIONS:
   A.   The mayor, upon recommendation of the license official, may deny the
issuance of a license if the applicant has:
      1.   Been convicted of a felony or any crime involving moral turpitude;
or
      2.   Obtained, or has aided another to obtain, a license by fraud,
deceit, material misrepresentation or material omission; or
      3.   Failed to pay any applicable taxes or fees; or
      4.   Violated the laws of the state, the United States government, the
ordinances of the city, or the rules and regulations of any Utah state or city
agency governing operation of the business holding the license or permit.
   B.   The reason for denial shall be endorsed on the application by the
license official, and the city recorder shall return to the applicant, via
certified mail, return receipt requested, the application, notice of the
applicant's rights to an appeal and any fees that are refundable. (Ord. 05-14,
4-6-2005)
5.08.140: APPEAL HEARING:
If the applicant files a written notice of appeal within twenty (20) days of
the notice of denial, a hearing to consider the denial of a license shall be
held as provided in chapter 5.11 of this title. Unless the mayor or hearing
examiner orders otherwise, it shall be unlawful for an applicant who has been
denied a license to commence or conduct the business or occupation contemplated
in the application. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.08.150: EFFECT OF DENIAL:
If at any time a license or renewal is denied under the provisions of this
chapter, it shall thereafter be unlawful for any person to engage in or carry
on or operate or use or permit to be operated or used, any property for any
business with respect to which the license or renewal has been denied, until a
license or renewal shall be granted by the city. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
CHAPTER 5.10
LICENSE SUSPENSION, REVOCATION, OR DENIAL TO RENEW
SECTION:
5.10.010: Enforcement Powers
5.10.020: Grounds For License Suspension, Revocation Or Denial To Renew
5.10.030: Notice Of Violation And Hearing
5.10.040: Waiting Period For New License
5.10.010: ENFORCEMENT POWERS:
The city shall be responsible for the enforcement of this title. The city may,
on its own initiative, or in response to complaints referred from the general
public or otherwise, investigate and gather evidence of violations of the
licensing provisions of this title. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.10.020: GROUNDS FOR LICENSE SUSPENSION, REVOCATION OR DENIAL TO RENEW:
In addition to any fine imposed, every license or permit issued by the city may
be revoked, suspended or renewal denied as prescribed herein. Upon
recommendation of the license official and upon a hearing held pursuant to
chapter 5.11 of this title, the mayor or hearing examiner may revoke, suspend
or deny renewal of licenses or permits, if the licensee or permittee:
   A.   Has been convicted of a felony or any crime involving moral turpitude;
   B.   Has obtained, or aided another to obtain, a license by fraud or deceit;
   C.   Has failed to pay any applicable taxes or fees;
   D.   Has violated the laws of the state, the United States government, the
ordinances of the city, or the rules and regulations of any agency of the city
or the state governing the operation of the business holding a license or
permit; or
   E.   Has refused to permit authorized officers or employees to make an
inspection or to take a sample of a commodity, or has interfered with such
officer or employee while in the performance of his duty in making such
inspection. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.10.030: NOTICE OF VIOLATION AND HEARING:
The city shall send the licensee written notice by certified mail, return
receipt requested, in care of the process agent specified in the license
application, of the alleged violation and notice of hearing and the licensee's
right to appear at the hearing, the consequences of the failure to appear and
answer, and of the date, time and place set for the hearing. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-
2005)
5.10.040: WAITING PERIOD FOR NEW LICENSE:
No person denied a license, or whose license has been revoked under the
provisions of this chapter, and no person associated or connected with such
person in conduct of such business shall be granted a license for the same
purpose for a period of six (6) months after the denial or revocation has
occurred. However, the mayor may, in his discretion, waive the prohibition
against persons formerly associated or connected with an individual who has had
his license revoked. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
CHAPTER 5.11
HEARINGS; DECISION; ENFORCEMENT; APPEAL
SECTION:
5.11.010: Hearing Procedure
5.11.020: Hearing Examiner; Appointment And Powers
5.11.030: Unlawful To Operate Without A License
5.11.010: HEARING PROCEDURE:
   A.   A suspension, revocation, or denial to renew a license issued pursuant
to the ordinances of the city shall not be imposed until a hearing is first
held pursuant to this chapter before the mayor or a hearing examiner.
   B.   At least twenty (20) days prior to a hearing hereunder, the city shall
cause notice of the time and place of the hearing to be served upon the
licensee or applicant by mailing a copy to the licensee or applicant via
certified mail, return receipt requested, in care of the licensee specified in
the license or applicant specified in the application.
   C.   Failure to appear at such hearing or otherwise defend against
suspension, revocation, denial of a license or denial to renew a license shall
constitute grounds for immediate suspension, revocation, denial of a license or
denial to renew a license.
   D.   All witnesses called at a hearing shall be sworn by a person duly
authorized to administer oaths, and a record of such hearing shall be made by a
recording or a court reporter. A licensee or applicant shall have the right to
appear at the hearing in person or by counsel, or both, present evidence,
present argument on the applicant's behalf, cross examine witnesses, and in all
proper ways defend the licensee or applicant's position.
   E.   Within ten (10) days after the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing
officer shall issue a written findings of fact, conclusions of law and order
based upon and supported by the evidence presented at such hearing. (Ord. 05-
14, 4-6-2005)
5.11.020: HEARING EXAMINER; APPOINTMENT AND POWERS:
A hearing officer shall be appointed by the mayor upon the advice and consent
of the city council. The hearing officer shall have power and authority to
call, preside at and conduct hearings to consider the suspension, revocation,
denial or approval of licenses or renewals issued by the city, including the
power to examine witnesses and receive evidence, compel the attendance of
witnesses, and compel the production of documents. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.11.030: UNLAWFUL TO OPERATE WITHOUT A LICENSE:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to commence or conduct any
business, trade or occupation within the city without first procuring all
applicable city business licenses.
   B.   If at any time a license issued under the provisions of this title is
denied, suspended or revoked, it shall thereafter be unlawful for the holder of
such license to conduct business on the premises described in such application
or license until the old license is reinstated or a new license is issued.
(Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
CHAPTER 5.12
LICENSE TRANSFERABILITY
SECTION:
5.12.010: License Transfer Limitations
5.12.020: Transfer Fee Or Fee For Changes In Business, Location, Name Or
Ownership
5.12.010: LICENSE TRANSFER LIMITATIONS:
   A.   No license granted or issued under the provisions of the ordinances of
the city shall be deemed to be assignable or transferable, or to authorize any
person other than the person therein to do business, or to authorize the
conduct of business other than at the location therein named.
   B.   Persons to whom one or more licenses have been issued to transact or
conduct business at one location in the city may make application for the
transfer of said licenses for the purpose of transacting the same business at
another location in the city. Applications for transfer shall be filed with the
license official ten (10) days in advance of the proposed change. The city,
after receiving recommendations from the license official or his authorized
agent may, at its discretion, grant or deny the transfer of licenses. No
transfer shall be permitted without full compliance with the building and
zoning requirements of this code.
   C.   Alcohol licenses are not transferable. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.12.020: TRANSFER FEE OR FEE FOR CHANGES IN BUSINESS LOCATION, NAME OR
OWNERSHIP:
In the event of a transfer of business location as described in section
5.12.010 of this chapter or in the event of a change in the business name or
ownership, a new license will be issued provided the appropriate fee is paid as
specified in the fee schedule adopted pursuant to section
5.06.040 of this title. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
CHAPTER 5.14
TEMPORARY LICENSES
SECTION:
5.14.010: Definitions
5.14.020: Required
5.14.030: Display
5.14.040: Fee
5.14.050: Application
5.14.060: Expedited License Charge
5.14.070: Location
5.14.080: Limitations And Restrictions
5.14.090: Exceptions
5.14.100: Inspection Of Merchandise
5.14.110: Cleanup Bond Required
5.14.120: Compliance With Laws
5.14.130: Signs
5.14.140: Temporary Automobile Sales
5.14.150: Temporary Christmas Tree Lots
5.14.160: Temporary Fireworks Stands
5.14.170: Temporary Food Vendors
5.14.180: Temporary Fruit Or Vegetable Stands
5.14.190: Temporary Merchants
5.14.010: DEFINITIONS:
FIREWORKS: Class C explosives as described in Utah Code Annotated section 53-7-
202.
TEMPORARY AUTOMOBILE SALES LOT: The conduct of business from a single
designated site, without a permanent foundation or location, from which new or
used automobiles are sold on a temporary basis.
TEMPORARY BUSINESS: The conduct of business from a single designated site or
premises without a permanent foundation or location, from which goods or
services are sold on a temporary or seasonal basis and includes a concert,
fair, rally, bazaar or festival.
TEMPORARY CHRISTMAS TREE LOT: The conduct of business from a single designated
site, without a permanent foundation or location, from which Christmas trees
are sold on a temporary basis.
TEMPORARY FIREWORKS SALES: The conduct of temporary retail sales of fireworks
from an existing retail store currently licensed by the city of Taylorsville to
perform retail sales.
TEMPORARY FIREWORKS STAND: The conduct of business from a single designated
site, without a permanent foundation or location, from which fireworks are sold
on a temporary basis.
TEMPORARY FOOD VENDOR: The conduct of business from a single designated site,
without a permanent foundation or location, from which prepared food and/or
beverages are sold on a temporary basis.
TEMPORARY FRUIT OR VEGETABLE STAND: The conduct of business from a single
designated site, without a permanent foundation or location, from which fresh
fruit and/or vegetables are sold on a temporary basis.
TEMPORARY MERCHANT: The conduct of business from a single designated site,
without a permanent foundation or location, from which goods or services and
nonfood items, other than fireworks, Christmas trees, and automobiles, are sold
on a temporary basis. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.14.020: REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any person to conduct, engage in, promote or carry on a
temporary business within the city without first making application for and
obtaining a temporary business license from the city. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.14.030: DISPLAY:
A temporary business license granted pursuant to this chapter must be
conspicuously displayed in or at the site or premises where the temporary
business is conducted and must be available for inspection. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-
2005)
5.14.040: FEE:
The fee for engaging in, carrying on, or conducting a temporary business shall
be as specified in the fee schedule. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.14.050: APPLICATION:
An application for a temporary business license must be submitted ten (10) days
prior to the commencement of the temporary business and must include the
following:
   A.   Site plan delineating where the temporary business will be located and
the parking area available for patrons. (Note: Needs further analysis to ensure
compliance with zoning regulations.)
   B.   Written permission from the property owner where the temporary business
will be located in a form acceptable to the city.
   C.   Acceptable evidence of a special event sales tax number issued by the
state of Utah. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.14.060: EXPEDITED LICENSE CHARGE:
The license official may waive the ten (10) working day requirement of section
 5.14.050 of this chapter upon payment of an expedited license charge in the
amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.14.070: LOCATION:
The temporary business license shall specify the location at which the
temporary business may be conducted, and no temporary business may be conducted
at any other location without first obtaining a separate license for that
location. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.14.080: LIMITATIONS AND RESTRICTIONS:
Each person conducting business under this chapter shall:
   A.   Provide suitable containers for placement of any litter by customers or
other persons; and clean up any paper, cardboard, wood, plastic containers,
wrappers, residues from any liquid spilled on the site, or litter of any kind
within a fifty foot (50') area.
   B.   Display in a prominent and visible manner the business license issued
by the city and conspicuously post the price of all items sold.
   C.   Obey the lawful order of a police officer to move temporarily to a
different location to avoid congestion or obstruction of the sidewalk, parking
lot, or plaza or to remove the vending cart entirely from the site, if
necessary, to avoid such congestion or obstruction.
   D.   Conduct no temporary business at a location other than that designated
on his/her permit with the exception as stated in subsection C of this section.
   E.   Make no loud or unreasonable noise of any kind by vocalization or
otherwise for the purpose of advertising or attracting attention to his or her
wares.
   F.   Submit written approval from the property owner to locate on the site.
(Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.14.090: EXCEPTIONS:
A temporary business license is not required for the following:
   A.   A vegetable and fruit stand that sells produce grown solely on property
owned or leased by the operator of the vegetable and fruit stand and such
property is located in the city.
   B.   Isolated or occasional sales from a private home by a person not
regularly engaged in business. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.14.100: INSPECTION OF MERCHANDISE:
The Taylorsville police department or other city official may inspect all goods
and merchandise to be sold pursuant to a temporary business license. (Ord. 05-
14, 4-6-2005)
5.14.110: CLEANUP BOND REQUIRED:
Any person applying for a temporary business license shall file, along with his
temporary business license application, a cash bond or irrevocable letter of
credit in an amount established pursuant to rules and regulations of the health
department. Such bonds shall cover the cost of disposing of all litter, garbage
and sewage of the individuals attending, observing or performing at the
temporary business license location. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.14.120: COMPLIANCE WITH LAWS:
Temporary license holders shall comply with all applicable laws and ordinances
of the city, planning and zoning requirements, and any state laws governing the
operation of its business. In addition, all temporary businesses must receive
approval from the city and any appropriate agencies, including, but not limited
to, the fire, health, and police departments. Noncompliance with any city
ordinance may result in immediate revocation of the temporary business license.
(Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.14.130: SIGNS:
All signs associated with temporary businesses shall comply with all standards
and regulations of the Taylorsville land development code. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-
2005; amd. Ord. 12-15, 7-11-2012)
5.14.140: TEMPORARY AUTOMOBILE SALES:
   A.   Temporary automobile sales are limited to no more than eight (8)
consecutive days per licensee or dealership for any and all locations within
the city. No licensee or dealership may obtain more than six (6) permits per
calendar year.
   B.   Any licensee or dealership making application for a temporary sale must
include with their application an off site car sale permit from the state of
Utah. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.14.150: TEMPORARY CHRISTMAS TREE LOTS:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of selling
Christmas trees without first obtaining a license from the city to do so for
each location.
   B.   Each applicant shall provide verification that the applicant has a bona
fide title to the trees and that they were not obtained illegally.
   C.   Each applicant shall file with the city a cash bond or irrevocable
letter of credit, made payable to the city, in the amount of three hundred
fifty dollars ($350.00) for each location. Such bond or irrevocable letter of
credit shall assure compliance with the provisions of this section, including,
but not limited to, the removal of the lot and the cleaning of the site where
it is located. Such bond or irrevocable letter of credit may be forfeited when
damage has resulted.
   D.   Lighting for temporary Christmas tree lots shall be by electric light
only, and all temporary power shall comply with the applicable electrical code.
   E.   Temporary Christmas tree lots may operate from one week prior to
Thanksgiving through December 25. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.14.160: TEMPORARY FIREWORKS STANDS:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of selling
fireworks without first obtaining a license from the city to do so for each
location.
   B.   All applications to sell fireworks must include insurance certificates
evidencing public liability insurance coverage in the amount of two hundred
thousand dollars/four hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00/$400,000.00), and
property damage insurance coverage in the amount of two hundred thousand
dollars ($200,000.00), and such certificates shall designate the city as an
additional insured, and include certificates evidencing products liability
insurance in an amount not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per
occurrence.
   C.   Each applicant for a temporary fireworks stand shall file with the city
a cash bond or irrevocable letter of credit, made payable to the city, in the
amount of three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) for each location. Such bond or
irrevocable letter of credit shall assure compliance with the provisions of
this section, including, but not limited to, the removal of the stand and the
cleaning of the site where it was located. Such bond or irrevocable letter of
credit may be forfeited when damage has resulted.
   D.   All persons or entities selling fireworks in the city of Taylorsville
shall conform to the following general requirements:
      1.   Sale and possession of fireworks are limited to those listed and
approved by the Utah state fire marshal.
      2.   All fireworks retail sales locations shall be under the direct
supervision of a responsible person who is eighteen (18) years of age or older.
      3.   Fireworks cannot be sold to a person under the age of sixteen (16)
unless accompanied by an adult.
      4.   No temporary fireworks stand shall be within twenty five feet (25')
of any building, structure, or any other temporary fireworks stand or within
fifty feet (50') of any gasoline pump, or gasoline dispensing service, or LPG
tank or dispensing device.
      5.   All weeds and combustible materials shall be cleared from within
twenty five feet (25') of any temporary fireworks stand.
      6.   All sale locations must have on premises at least one "2A10BC" rated
fire extinguisher.
      7.   Temporary fireworks stands less than one hundred twenty (120) square
feet need not comply with the provisions of the uniform building code, but all
such stands shall be erected in a manner that will reasonably assure the safety
of occupants and patrons.
      8.   Temporary fireworks stands one hundred twenty (120) square feet or
larger must conform to all fire and building code requirements.
      9.   Lighting of temporary fireworks stands shall be by electric light
only and all temporary power shall comply with the applicable electrical code.
      10.   Signs bearing the message "Discharge of Fireworks Prohibited Within
One Hundred Feet of this Location" and "Smoking Prohibited Within Twenty Five
Feet of this Location" in letters at least three inches (3") tall shall be
attached and conspicuously displayed on all four (4) sides of the temporary
fireworks stand.
      11.   Fireworks may not be stored in residences or attached garages.
      12.   The storage or selling of fireworks shall not by its presence,
create a distinct hazard to any person or property.
      13.   Fireworks may only be sold from June 20 through July 25, and
December 20 through January 2, and fifteen (15) days before and on Chinese New
Year.
      14.   Fireworks may be discharged three (3) days prior to, or on the day
of, and three (3) days following July 4, July 24, January 1, and the Chinese
New Year.
      15.   Display of fireworks inside a building or temporary fireworks stand
shall be located to ensure constant visual supervision.
      16.   Temporary fireworks sales in permanent structures must be separated
from flammable and combustible gases, liquids, and solids by at least fifty
feet (50').
      17.   Temporary fireworks sales in permanent structures must be located
in such a manner as to not impede egress from the building. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-
2005)
5.14.170: TEMPORARY FOOD VENDORS:
   A.   All temporary food vendors are required to obtain approval and comply
with the Salt Lake Valley health department regulations for preparing and
operating a food cart.
   B.   A temporary food vendor shall not operate within one thousand feet
(1,000') of another food vendor or a restaurant, or a business which offers
similar food, without written permission of the business owner or manager.
   C.   Licenses for temporary food vendors shall expire sixty (60) days from
issuance. A licensee may reapply for subsequent licenses at the same location
but may not exceed one hundred eighty (180) days at the same location. For the
purposes of this section, any location within two hundred fifty (250) linear
feet is considered the same location. Temporary food vendors who are properly
licensed at a given location will have the right of first refusal for
subsequent temporary license renewals provided the licensee has not reached the
maximum permissible license duration. The business license or land use fee
shall be waived with subsequent licenses in the one hundred eighty (180) day
period at the same location by the same applicant as referenced above.
   D.   Prior to the issuance of any permit, the fire marshal or his designee,
shall inspect and approve any mobile device or pushcart containing cooking or
heating equipment to assure the conformance of any such equipment with the
provisions of the fire code. (Ord. 05-36, 7-6-2005)
5.14.180: TEMPORARY FRUIT OR VEGETABLE STANDS:
   A.   A vendor selling fruit and/or vegetables from a cart, stand or mobile
structure, shall be required to place all produce upon stands or in boxes,
which shall be kept at least six inches (6") above the ground.
   B.   A temporary business license is not required for a vegetable or fruit
stand that sells produce grown solely on property owned or leased by the
operator of the vegetable and fruit stand and such property is located within
the city.
   C.   Licenses for temporary fruit or vegetable stands shall expire thirty
(30) days from issuance. A licensee may reapply for subsequent licenses at the
same location but may not exceed ninety (90) days at the same location. For the
purposes of this section, any location within two hundred fifty (250) linear
feet is considered the same location. Temporary fruit and vegetable stand
vendors who are properly licensed at a given location will have the right of
first refusal for subsequent temporary license renewals provided the licensee
has not reached the maximum permissible license duration. The business license
or land use fee shall be waived with subsequent licenses in the ninety (90) day
period at the same location by the same applicant as referenced above. (Ord.
05-36, 7-6-2005)
5.14.190: TEMPORARY MERCHANTS:
   A.   All product changes require a new business license prior to
distribution of new merchandise.
   B.   Licenses for temporary merchants shall expire thirty (30) days from
issuance. A licensee may reapply for subsequent licenses at the same location
but may not exceed sixty (60) days at the same location. For the purposes of
this section, any location within two hundred fifty (250) linear feet is
considered the same location. Temporary merchants who are properly licensed at
a given location will have the right of first refusal for subsequent temporary
license renewals provided the licensee has not reached the maximum permissible
license duration. The business license or land use fee shall be waived with
subsequent licenses in the sixty (60) day period at the same location by the
same applicant as referenced above. (Ord. 05-36, 7-6-2005)
CHAPTER 5.16
BOARD OF LICENSE EQUALIZATION
SECTION:
5.16.010: City Council; Powers And Duties
5.16.020: Council Meetings
5.16.030: Complaints On Assessments; Deadline For Presentation
5.16.010: CITY COUNCIL; POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The city council hereby constitutes the board of license equalization
for the equalization of license fees and penalties. The board shall have
authority to examine the assessments made by the license official, hear
complaints of aggrieved parties, and make changes in any assessments the city
council concludes to be illegal, unequal, or unjust.
   B.   Corrections made by the city council shall be entered in detail in the
record of license assessment kept by the license official, and the city council
shall approve in writing such entries before the license official shall adjust
the accounts. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.16.020: COUNCIL MEETINGS:
The city council shall meet as often as shall be necessary to complete the
business of equalization. The date, time and place of each meeting shall be set
by the majority vote of the city council during a regular session of the city
council. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.16.030: COMPLAINTS ON ASSESSMENTS; DEADLINE FOR PRESENTATION:
All complaints relative to an assessment made by the license official must be
presented to the city council within six (6) months after such assessment, or
be forever barred. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
CHAPTER 5.18
REGISTRATION CARDS
SECTION:
5.18.010: Definitions
5.18.020: Persons And Establishments Which Require Registration Cards
5.18.030: Out Of State Entertainers; Group Work Card
5.18.040: Procedure For Obtaining Card
5.18.050: Fees
5.18.060: Card Numbers To Be Registered By Employer
5.18.070: Examination Of Employees' Cards
5.18.080: Possession Of Card Required; Cards Not Transferable
5.18.090: Denial Conditions; Appeals
5.18.100: Revocation Conditions; Appeals
5.18.110: Violation; Penalty
5.18.010: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
DEPARTMENT: Shall mean and include the Taylorsville police department.
EMPLOYED: Performing any type of work or assistance for or on behalf of any
establishment covered by this chapter, at any establishment covered by this
chapter, during hours such establishment is open to its members or to the
public, whether or not pecuniary compensation is provided or offered therefor.
EMPLOYEE: Any person, female or male, who is "employed", as defined in this
section, by any establishment covered by this chapter, whether the person is
employed on a contractual basis, by fixed salary, or by any other means.
EMPLOYER: Any establishment, or the principals thereof, covered by this
chapter. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.18.020: PERSONS AND ESTABLISHMENTS WHICH REQUIRE REGISTRATION CARDS:
The persons and establishments covered by this chapter shall be all employees
of nonpremises beer establishments, limited restaurant licenses, on premises
taverns and special events licenses which provide live entertainment on the
premises, and class A, B, C and D private clubs which sell, serve and dispense
alcoholic beverages, including bartenders, waiters, waitresses, managers; those
engaged in the security or the checking of identification; and those providing
entertainment in such establishments are required to obtain a registration
card. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.18.030: OUT OF STATE ENTERTAINERS; GROUP WORK CARD:
It shall be the responsibility of a licensee of an establishment listed in
section
5.18.020 of this chapter desiring an out of state entertainer or entertainment
group to perform on the licensee's premises to ensure that the entertainer or
each member of the entertainment group has either obtained a work card or a
group work card for the entertainer or entertainment group, as appropriate. The
licensee shall submit the name, date of birth and address of each entertainer
or member of the entertainment group and shall verify that each entertainer or
each member of the entertainment group is over the age of twenty one (21). The
application for a group work card shall contain all information required by the
department and shall be submitted to the department by the licensee twenty four
(24) hours prior to the performance of the entertainer or the entertainment
group. The group work card shall be valid for only the performance of the
entertainer or entertainment group while at the licensee's premises, but in no
event shall it be valid for longer than ten (10) days. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.18.040: PROCEDURE FOR OBTAINING CARD:
   A.   Prior to commencing employment, the employee must obtain a signed
registration application from the employer, and then submit himself to the
department to be photographed, or provide the department with two (2) one and
one-half inch by one and one- half inch (11/2" x 11/2") photographs.
   B.   Any applicant may be required to furnish satisfactory documented proof
of his or her age. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.18.050: FEES:
The fee for work cards shall be as specified in the fee schedule. (Ord. 05-14,
4-6-2005)
5.18.060: CARD NUMBERS TO BE REGISTERED BY EMPLOYER:
All department card numbers obtained under the provisions of this chapter are
to be registered by the employer personnel or payroll section and kept as a
part of the record of the employee. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.18.070: EXAMINATION OF EMPLOYEES' CARDS:
The person or persons designated by each establishment as the agent(s)
responsible for hiring and/or checking employees under the provisions of this
chapter shall examine each employee's or prospective employee's department card
for the purpose of determining the validity of the card for use in the
particular establishment concerned, such validity to be determined by the name
of the concerned establishment being stamped on the back side of the department
card in red ink. If the prospective employee's card is found to be invalid as
described above, he will be issued a new signed application form which must be
completed and presented along with his department card to the department for
validation, prior to commencing employment. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.18.080: POSSESSION OF CARD REQUIRED; CARDS NOT TRANSFERABLE:
All persons employed by an establishment governed by this chapter must have in
their possession a valid registration card. Registration cards are not
transferable. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.18.090: DENIAL CONDITIONS; APPEALS:
   A.   The police department may deny a registration card if the applicant:
      1.   Has been convicted of a felony or any crime involving moral
turpitude;
      2.   Has obtained a registration card by fraud or deceit;
      3.   Has failed to pay required fees; or
      4.   Has violated the laws of the state or the ordinances of the city
regulating the work of the applicant.
   B.   Any person who is denied a department registration card may appeal in
writing within fifteen (15) days from the date of denial to the city for a
hearing regarding issuance of the registration card. The city shall then
schedule a hearing in conformance with general business license denial
proceedings, as set forth in chapter 5.11 of this title, as amended. (Ord. 05-
14, 4-6-2005)
5.18.100: REVOCATION CONDITIONS; APPEALS:
   A.   The department may revoke or suspend registration cards if the holder:
      1.   Has been convicted of a felony or any crime involving moral
turpitude;
      2.   Has obtained a registration card by fraud or deceit;
      3.   Has failed to pay required fees;
      4.   Has violated the laws of the state or the ordinances of the city
regulating the work of the permit holder;
      5.   Has procured, attempted to procure, or agreed to procure, for any
person:
         a.   Another person for the purpose of sexual intercourse or any
immoral act, or
         b.   A controlled substance, as defined in Utah Code Annotated section
58-37-1 et seq.;
      6.   Has utilized his registration card for the purpose of obtaining
credit, or as identification for cashing checks.
   B.   Any person whose registration card has been revoked or suspended by the
department may appeal within fifteen (15) days from the date of the suspension
or revocation to the city for a hearing regarding reinstatement of the
registration card. The city shall then schedule a hearing in conformance with
general license revocation proceedings, as set forth in chapter 5.11 of this
title, as amended. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.18.110: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
Any person in violation of this chapter is guilty of a class C misdemeanor as
defined in state law. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
CHAPTER 5.20
INSPECTIONS
SECTION:
5.20.010: Officers Authorized To Examine And Inspect Businesses; Powers And
Duties
5.20.020: Right Of Entry; Sampling Of Materials
5.20.030: Complaints And Citations For Violation
5.20.010: OFFICERS AUTHORIZED TO EXAMINE AND INSPECT BUSINESSES; POWERS AND
DUTIES:
A police officer, the license official or members of his staff and the fire
chief and his designated representatives, are hereby appointed ex officio
license deputies who, in addition to the several duties of their respective
offices or positions, are hereby authorized and empowered to examine and
inspect all places of business subject to paying a license under the provisions
of this title as their duty shall bring them into contact with same, inspect
and verify all information listed on the license application and to see that
businesses covered and authorized by the license issued are carried on or
transacted in accordance with this title and other applicable law, and to
report to the license official the names of all persons doing business without
a license, and instances of the conduct by any party or business other than
that covered by the license issued. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.20.020: RIGHT OF ENTRY; SAMPLING OF MATERIALS:
   A.   Whenever inspections of the premises used for or in connection with the
operation of a licensed business or occupation are provided for or required by
ordinance, or are reasonably necessary to secure compliance with any ordinance
provision, or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the
licensee, or the person in charge of the premises to be inspected, to admit
thereto, for the purpose of making the inspection, any officer, employee or
agent of the license official who is authorized and directed to make such
inspections at any reasonable time that admission is requested.
   B.   Whenever an analysis of any commodity or material is reasonably
necessary to secure conformance with ordinance provisions, or to detect
violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the licensee whose business is
governed by such provision to give to any authorized officer or employee
requesting the same sufficient samples of such material or commodity as are
necessary for analysis. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.20.030: COMPLAINTS AND CITATIONS FOR VIOLATION:
The license official and his authorized deputies shall, in the discharge and
performance of their official duties, have and exercise the power to issue
citations for the violation of any of the provisions of the license ordinances.
The license official shall further have the duty of cooperating with the city
attorney to cause complaints to be filed against all persons violating any of
the provisions of the license ordinances. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
CHAPTER 5.22
ALARM SYSTEMS; INTRUSION AND PHYSICAL DURESS
SECTION:
5.22.010: Purpose And Scope
5.22.020: Definitions
5.22.030: Registration Required To Operate Alarm System Business And Automatic
Dialing Devices
5.22.040: Individual Employee's Registration
5.22.050: User Instructions
5.22.060: Response To Alarms; Permit Revocation
5.22.070: Interagency Communications
5.22.080: Deliberate False Alarms
5.22.090: Policies
5.22.100: City Liability Limitation
5.22.110: Penalties
5.22.010: PURPOSE AND SCOPE:
   A.   The purpose of this section is to protect the emergency services of the
city from misuse.
   B.   This section governs intrusion and physical duress alarm systems,
requires permits and registration, establishes fees, provides for the
allocation of revenues and deficits, provides for revocation of the permit,
provides for punishment of violations and establishes a system of
administration. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.22.020: DEFINITIONS:
ALARM BUSINESS: The business by any individual, partnership, corporation or
other entity of selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, altering,
replacing, removing, moving, installing, planning the installation or assisting
in the installation of any alarm service.
ALARM SYSTEM: Any assembly of equipment, mechanical or electrical, arranged to
signal the occurrence of an illegal entry or other activity requiring urgent
attention and to which peace officers are expected to respond.
ALARM USER: The person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company,
or organization thereof of any kind in control of any building, structure or
facility wherein an alarm system is maintained.
AUTOMATIC DIALING DEVICE: A device which is interconnected to a telephone line
and is programmed to select a predetermined telephone number and transmit by
voice message or code signal any emergency message indicating a need for
emergency response.
COORDINATOR: The individual designated by the police department to issue
permits and enforce the provisions of this section.
FALSE ALARM: An alarm signal eliciting a response by peace officers when a
situation requiring a response by them or other emergency response unit in fact
does not exist. It includes an alarm signal caused by conditions of nature
which are normal for that area and subject to control by the alarm business
operator or alarm user. "False alarm" does not include an alarm signal caused
by extraordinarily violent conditions of nature not reasonably subject to
control.
INTERCONNECT: To connect an alarm system, including an automatic dialing
device, to a telephone line, either directly or through a mechanical device
that utilizes a telephone, for the purpose of using the telephone line to
transmit a message upon the activation of the alarm system.
INTRUSION ALARM SYSTEM: An alarm system signaling an entry or attempted entry
into the area protected by the system.
LOCAL ALARM: Any noise making alarm device.
PHYSICAL DURESS SYSTEM: An alarm system signaling a robbery or other physical
endangerment.
POLICE DEPARTMENT: The Taylorsville police department.
PRIMARY TRUNK LINE: A telephone line serving the Valley 911 system or other
dispatch services that is designated to receive emergency calls.
VALLEY 911 AND POLICE DISPATCH: The governmental facilities used to receive
emergency and general information from the public to be dispatched to the
police department. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.22.030: REGISTRATION REQUIRED TO OPERATE ALARM SYSTEM BUSINESS AND AUTOMATIC
DIALING DEVICES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person, partnership, corporation or
association to own, manage, conduct or carry on the business of selling,
leasing, installing, servicing, maintaining, repairing, replacing, moving or
removing, or causing to be sold, leased, installed, serviced, maintained,
repaired, replaced, moved or removed in or on any building, residence or other
property within the city any device known as an intrusion, or physical duress
alarm system, or automatic dialing device connected to an answering service,
unless such person is licensed therefor in accordance with Utah Code Annotated
section 58-55-101 et seq., and any other applicable laws.
   B.   The fee for an intrusion or physical duress alarm system business
license shall be as specified on the fee schedule.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain, operate, connect, or
allow maintaining, operating or connecting, any automatic dialing device which
automatically dials the police department and then relays any prerecorded
message to report any robbery, burglary, or other emergency. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-
2005)
5.22.040: INDIVIDUAL EMPLOYEE'S REGISTRATION:
It shall be unlawful for any person employed by a person having a valid license
as an alarm business or company under Utah Code Annotated section 58-55-101 et
seq., to engage directly in the selling, leasing, installing, servicing,
maintaining, repairing, moving or removing in or on any building or other
property within the city any intrusion or physical duress alarm system unless
such person shall first be licensed therefor in accordance with all applicable
laws. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.22.050: USER INSTRUCTIONS:
Every alarm business selling, leasing or furnishing to any user an alarm system
which is installed on premises located in the city shall furnish the user with
written instructions that provide information to enable the user to operate the
alarm system properly. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.22.060: RESPONSE TO ALARMS; PERMIT REVOCATION:
Except for alarms at a wholesale or retail firearms business, intrusion alarm
response shall be dispatched by the police department only after a private
guard responder has confirmed that an attempted or actual crime has occurred at
the alarm site. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.22.070: INTERAGENCY COMMUNICATIONS:
A central station or other alarm dispatch center must provide the police
dispatch a toll free telephone number for the conducting of business and
contacting the central station dispatchers at the time of filing the alarm
report. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.22.080: DELIBERATE FALSE ALARMS:
No person shall cause to be transmitted any intrusion or physical duress alarm
knowing the same to be false or without basis in fact. Central stations shall
not request law enforcement officers to respond to alarm scenes when monitoring
equipment indicates an alarm system malfunction signal. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.22.090: POLICIES:
The city council may from time to time adopt or modify by ordinance written
policies governing the allocation of the city's law enforcement resources and
other emergency services to alarm systems. Such policies may, without
limitation, prohibit response by the city's law enforcement personnel to alarms
of specific types, specify the conditions under which the city's law
enforcement personnel will respond to alarms of specific types, or in any other
manner control and protect from misuse the city's emergency services. (Ord. 05-
14, 4-6-2005)
5.22.100: CITY LIABILITY LIMITATION:
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, the timing of any response to an
alarm in any particular situation is dependent on a number of factors over
which the city has no control. Therefore, the city will have absolutely no
liability, contractual or otherwise, to any provider or to any alarm user, if
response to is not timely. Further, the city will not be liable for any defect
in the operation of intrusion or duress alarm systems. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.22.110: PENALTIES:
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
class B misdemeanor as defined by state law. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
CHAPTER 5.24
ALCOHOL AND BEER
SECTION:
5.24.010: Adoption Of Utah Alcoholic Beverage Control Act
5.24.020: Definitions
5.24.030: Business License Required - Sales At Wholesale
5.24.040: Business License Required - Sales At Retail
5.24.050: Application For Alcoholic Product License
5.24.060: Alcoholic Product License Issuance
5.24.070: Alcoholic Product License Suspension And Revocation
5.24.080: Expiration Date
5.24.090: City License Requires State License
5.24.100: Licensee Qualifications
5.24.110: Fees
5.24.120: Alcoholic Product License Renewal
5.24.130: Name Changes
5.24.140: Civil Fine
(Previous Chapter 5.24 repealed and replaced by Ord. 20-06, 7-1-2020)
5.24.010: ADOPTION OF UTAH ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE CONTROL ACT:
The alcoholic beverage control act, Utah Code Annotated sections 32B-1-101 et
seq., as amended from time to time, is hereby adopted by this reference in its
entirety as if set forth in full herein. The alcoholic beverage control act as
adopted herein shall be construed to apply only to the incorporated areas of
the city and shall be interpreted and constructed where necessary to carry out
the intent of this chapter. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005; amd. Ord. 20-06, 7-1-2020)
5.24.020: DEFINITIONS:
All words and phrases used in this chapter shall have the same meaning given to
them in the alcoholic beverage control act. In addition, the following words
and phrases shall have the following additional meanings, unless a different
meaning clearly appears from the context:
APPLICATION: A formal written request for the issuance of a city permit or
license.
CITY: The city of Taylorsville.
CITY COUNCIL: The city council of the city.
FEE SCHEDULE: The city's fee schedule adopted pursuant to section
5.06.040 of this title.
PLACE OF BUSINESS: Shall include cafes, restaurants, public dining rooms,
cafeterias, taverns, cabarets, and any other place where the general public is
invited or admitted for business purposes, and shall be deemed to include
private clubs, corporations and associations operating under charter or
otherwise wherein only the members, visitors and their guests are invited.
Occupied hotel(s) and motel(s) that are not open to the public shall not be
deemed to be places of business as herein defined.
PUBLIC PLACE: Means and refers to any of the following which are open to and
generally used by the public: streets, roads and alleys; state or county
highways or roads; buildings and grounds used for school purposes, and public
dance halls and adjacent grounds; any place of public resort or amusement;
lobbies, halls, and dining rooms of hotels, restaurants, theaters, stores,
garages, and service stations; any public conveyance and its depots and waiting
rooms which are open to unrestricted use and access by the public; publicly
owned bathing beaches, parks or playground; and all other places which under
this chapter have been declared to be a public place.
RETAILER: Any person engaged in the sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages
to the consumer.
WHOLESALER: Any person engaged in the importation for sale, or in the sale of
beer in wholesale or jobbing quantities to retailers, other than a small brewer
selling beer manufactured by that brewer. (Ord. 10-32, 11-10-2010; amd. Ord.
20-06, 7-1-2020)
5.24.030: BUSINESS LICENSE REQUIRED - SALES AT WHOLESALE:
It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of selling alcoholic
products at wholesale within the city without first obtaining(1) a license from
the Utah Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control; (2) a general business
license from the city; and (3) a wholesale alcoholic product license from the
city. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005; amd. Ord. 20-06, 7-1-2020)
5.24.040: BUSINESS LICENSE REQUIRED - SALES AT RETAIL:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of selling
alcoholic products at retail within the city without first obtaining (1) a
license from the Utah Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control; (2) a general
business license from the city; and (3) a retail alcoholic product license from
the city. A separate retail alcoholic product license is required for each
location or place of business where alcoholic products are sold.(Ord. 05-14, 4-
6-2005; amd. Ord. 20-06, 7-1-2020)
5.24.050: APPLICATION FOR ALCOHOLIC PRODUCT LICENSE:
   A.   Each person or entity interested in obtaining an alcoholic product
license shall file an alcoholic product license application with the city's
business license official.
   B.   All alcoholic product license applications submitted to the city shall
be referred to the Salt Lake County Health Department, which shall inspect the
premises to be licensed to assure sanitary compliance with the laws of the
state, the ordinances of the city, and health department rules and regulations
on the preparation, storage, distribution or sale of beer and food. If the Salt
Lake County Health Department determines that the premises fulfill all such
sanitary requirements, the Salt Lake County Health Department shall issue a
permit to the licensee, a copy of which shall be attached to the alcoholic
beverage product license application submitted to the city.
   C.   All alcoholic product license applications submitted to the city shall
also be referred to the Unified Police Department Taylorsville Precinct for
inspection and report. The Unified Police Department Taylorsville Precinct
shall, within ten (10) days after receiving an alcoholic product license
application, write a report detailing: (1) the nature and the kind of business
conducted by the applicant at the proposed location; (2) whether the proposed
location is or has been conducted in a lawful, quiet and orderly manner; (3)
the nature and kind of entertainment, if any, at the proposed location; (4)
whether gambling is or has been permitted at the proposed location or by the
applicant at any other place; (5) the proximity of such premises to any
community location; and (6) the police department's recommendation as to
whether or not the alcoholic product license application should be granted.
(Ord. 20-06, 7-1-2020)
5.24.060: ALCOHOLIC PRODUCT LICENSE ISSUANCE:
If the applicant has: (1) complied with all applicable laws, ordinances and
regulations; (2) received a permit from the Salt Lake County Health Department;
and (3) received a positive recommendation from the Unified Police Department
Taylorsville Precinct, then the Business License Official shall issue the
alcoholic product license to the applicant.  (Ord. 20-06, 7-1-2020)
5.24.070: ALCOHOLIC PRODUCT LICENSE SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION:
   A.   The city may revoke an alcoholic product license if a violation of this
chapter or any applicable ordinance or law relating to alcoholic beverages is
committed by the licensee or occurs on the licensed premises. The city may also
revoke an alcoholic product license if the licensee no longer qualifies for an
alcoholic product license pursuant to this chapter. 
   B.   An alcoholic product license may be suspended and the licensed premises
closed by the Salt Lake County sheriff without a prior hearing. At the time of
a suspension, notice shall be given to the licensee of the cause(s) of such
suspension and of the licensee's right to petition the city for a hearing
within ten (10) days after the date of such suspension. If cause for the
suspension is established at the hearing, the suspension order may be continued
for up to one year in duration. However, no license shall be revoked or
suspended beyond the initial hearing without first establishing cause therefor,
nor shall any license be revoked without first giving the licensee an
opportunity for a hearing on the cause(s) specified for revocation.
   C.   It is unlawful for any person to sell alcoholic beverages at the
licensed premises during such period of suspension, or after the revocation of
the person's alcoholic product license. (Ord. 20-06, 7-1-2020)
5.24.080: EXPIRATION DATE:
Alcoholic product licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall be valid for
one (1) year from the date the license was issued. (Ord. 20-06, 7-1-2020)
5.24.090: CITY LICENSE REQUIRES STATE LICENSE:
An alcoholic product license shall be issued by the city only in conjunction
with an applicable state license.  During any period an applicable state
license is not in effect for a given premises, whether by reason of suspension,
revocation or any other reason, the city license for the premises shall
automatically be suspended. Upon presentation of written proof that the
commission has reinstated or otherwise revalidated the applicable state
license, the city license shall be deemed to be valid and in full force and
effect. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit or restrict the
city from enforcing state law or city ordinance as allowed by law regarding
alcoholic beverage sales and licensing in the city.  (Ord. 20-06, 7-1-2020)
5.24.100: LICENSEE QUALIFICATIONS:
An alcoholic product license applicant shall be at least the age of twenty-one
(21) or over, a citizen of the United States or a permanent resident of the
United States (alien registration card required), and meet all applicable state
qualifications.
If an alcoholic product license applicant is a firm, partnership, association,
group, corporation, limited liability company, or any other business entity,
each partner, association member, corporate officer, director or any other
person having ownership interest in the business that is applying for a license
shall meet all of the foregoing restrictions as if such individuals were the
applicant. The operator or person having management responsibilities shall also
meet all of the foregoing restrictions. (Ord. 20-06, 7-1-2020)
5.24.110: FEES:
Alcoholic product licenses shall be subject to all applicable fees as outlined
in section 5.06.040. (Ord. 20-06, 7-1-2020)
5.24.120: ALCOHOLIC PRODUCT LICENSE RENEWAL:
Alcoholic product license renewal applications and all applicable renewal fees
as outlined in section 5.06.040 shall be submitted to the city at least thirty
(30) days prior to the expiration date of the then-issued alcoholic product
license. Any applicant who fails to submit a renewal application and all
applicable renewal fees before such deadline shall close the licensed premises
on the expiration date of the then-issued alcoholic product license and shall
keep the premises closed for any and all business involving the sale of
alcoholic beverages in the city until a new alcoholic product license is issued
by the city. (Ord. 20-06, 7-1-2020)
5.24.130: NAME CHANGES:
An alcoholic product license holder who wishes to change the name of the
business establishment shall give written notice of the name change to the city
at least ten (10) days prior to the name change and shall pay all applicable
fees as outlined in section 5.06.040.  (Ord. 20-06, 7-1-2020)
5.24.140: CIVIL FINE:
In addition to any civil or criminal remedy available to the city to enforce
the provisions of this chapter, a person who violates any provision of this
chapter is subject to a civil fine of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00)
for each violation. A civil fine is due and payable within twenty (20) days of
the date of citation from the city giving notice of the civil fine. Notice of a
civil fine shall be given by personal service or by posting in the United
States mail, postage paid, certified mail, return receipt requested. Unpaid
civil fines are a debt owed to the city and may be the subject of a civil
action filed in any court having legal jurisdiction. (Ord. 20-06, 7-1-2020)
5.24.150: REFERRAL TO POLICE DEPARTMENT:
   A.   All applications filed under section
5.24.130 of this chapter shall be referred to the police department or other
law enforcement contract provider for inspection and report. The police
department or other contract provider shall, within ten (10) days after
receiving such application, make report of:
      1.   The nature and the kind of business conducted at such place by the
applicant or by any other person or by the applicant at any other place;
      2.   Whether such place is or has been conducted in a lawful, quiet and
orderly manner;
      3.   The nature and kind of entertainment, if any, at such place;
      4.   Whether gambling is or has been permitted on the premises or by the
applicant at any other place; and
      5.   The proximity of such premises to any school or church.
   B.   The police department or other contract provider shall also add to such
report the recommendation as to whether or not the application should be
granted. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
CHAPTER 5.28
AMUSEMENT DEVICES, BILLIARD HALLS, POOL HALLS, BOWLING ALLEYS, CARD AND GAME
ROOMS, GOLF COURSE, AND MINIATURE GOLF
SECTION:
5.28.010: Definitions
5.28.020: Amusement Devices, Golf Course, Or Miniature Golf Course License
Required; Fees
5.28.030: Issuance Conditions
5.28.040: Devices To Be Kept In Plain View
5.28.050: Inspection Of Premises And Devices
5.28.060: Gambling Devices Not Authorized
5.28.070: Billiard And Pool Halls License Required
5.28.080: Billiard And Pool Hall Fees
5.28.090: Billiard And Pool Hall Hours Of Operation
5.28.100: Visibility Of The Interior
5.28.110: Restrictions Concerning Minors
5.28.120: Bowling Alleys License Required
5.28.130: Bowling Alley Fee
5.28.140: Separation Of Bowling And Lounge Areas
5.28.150: Card And Game Rooms Individual License Requirements
5.28.160: License Application; Contents
5.28.170: Investigation By The Police Department
5.28.180: Card And Game Room Fee
5.28.190: Periodic Inspections
5.28.200: License Revocation
5.28.210: Card And Game Room Hours Of Operation
5.28.220: Unobstructed View Of Tables
5.28.230: Locked Doors And Alarm Devices Prohibited
5.28.240: Alcoholic Beverages Prohibited
5.28.250: Playing For Money Prohibited
5.28.260: Known Gamblers Prohibited
5.28.010: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
AMUSEMENT DEVICE: Any machine, whether mechanically or electronically operated,
that upon insertion of a coin, trade token, slug or similar object, or upon
payment of money or other consideration through use of a metered or similar
device, operates or may be operated as a game or contest of skill or amusement,
of any kind or description, and that contains no automatic payoff for the
return of money or trade tokens, or that makes no provision whatever for the
return of money to the player. An amusement device is further defined as any
machine, apparatus or contrivance that is used or that may be used as a game of
skill and amusement wherein or whereby the player initiates, employs or directs
any force generated by the machine, but specifically excludes a "musical
mechanical amusement device" as herein defined.
DISTRIBUTOR: Any person, firm, corporation, partnership or association who sets
up for operation by another, leases, rents, sells, distributes, or in any way
provides for the purpose of operation any amusement device, whether for a fixed
charge or rental, or on the basis of a division of the income derived from such
devices, or otherwise.
GOLF COURSE: A tract of land laid out for playing golf.
MINIATURE GOLF COURSE: A tract of land laid out where a novelty version of golf
is played with a putter and golf balls, featuring various obstacles, such as
alleys, bridges, and/or tunnels.
MUSICAL MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICE: Means and includes each machine vending
recorded music, or a period of radio or television entertainment in return for
the insertion or deposit therein of a coin, trade token, slug, or similar
object; provided, however, that this does not include coin operated radios or
television sets in private quarters. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.020: AMUSEMENT DEVICES, GOLF COURSE, OR MINIATURE GOLF COURSE LICENSE
REQUIRED; FEES:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to install, operate
or maintain for public patronage or operation of an amusement device or musical
mechanical amusement device, golf course, or miniature golf course without
having first obtained a license therefor. Applications shall be made to the
license official.
   B.   The fee for such license shall be as specified on the fee schedule
adopted pursuant to section
5.06.040 of this title. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.030: ISSUANCE CONDITIONS:
One sticker shall be issued for each device licensed, and it shall be placed in
a conspicuous place and so affixed that it cannot be transferred from one
machine to another. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.040: DEVICES TO BE KEPT IN PLAIN VIEW:
All such devices shall at all times be kept in plain view of any person or
persons who may frequent or be in any place of business where such devices are
kept or used. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.050: INSPECTION OF PREMISES AND DEVICES:
The police department shall inspect or cause the inspection of any place or
building in which any such device or devices are operated or set up for
operation, and shall periodically inspect, investigate and test such devices.
(Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.060: GAMBLING DEVICES NOT AUTHORIZED:
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to authorize, permit or license any
gambling device of any nature whatsoever. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.070: BILLIARD AND POOL HALLS LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person, firm or corporation shall operate, maintain or conduct a billiard
and pool hall open to the public without having first obtained a license
therefor as is required in this chapter. All applications for such licenses
shall state thereon the intended location of the place of business and the
number of tables to be used therein. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.080: BILLIARD AND POOL HALL FEES:
The annual license fee for billiard and pool tables shall be as specified on
the fee schedule adopted pursuant to section
5.06.040 of this title. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.090: BILLIARD AND POOL HALL HOURS OF OPERATION:
No billiard and pool hall shall operate between the hours of two o'clock (2:00)
A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. If alcoholic beverages are sold on the
premises, the hours of operation shall be further limited (but not extended) to
the times specified in this code. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.100: VISIBILITY OF THE INTERIOR:
A clear, unobstructed view from the entrance of the entire interior of the
billiard and pool hall, excluding the restroom, shall be maintained by the
licensee at all times, nor shall the licensee erect or maintain any enclosed
booths, blinds or stalls within the interior of the licensed premises. (Ord.
10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.110: RESTRICTIONS CONCERNING MINORS:
In billiard and pool halls serving minors, no alcoholic beverages or cigarettes
shall be sold, dispensed, or consumed on or about the premises, which includes
the parking lot. Further, it is unlawful for licensees of billiard and pool
halls to operate the same in contravention of the curfew provisions outlined in
this code. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.120: BOWLING ALLEYS LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person, firm or corporation shall operate or maintain a bowling alley open
to the public without having first secured a license therefor as is required in
this chapter. Applications for such licenses shall be made to the license
official and shall be in writing and state thereon the intended location of the
place of business and the number of alleys to be used. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.130: BOWLING ALLEY FEE:
The annual license fee for a bowling alley shall be as specified in the fee
schedule adopted pursuant to section
 5.06.040 of this title. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.140: SEPARATION OF BOWLING AND LOUNGE AREAS:
It is unlawful to carry any alcoholic beverage into the area where bowling is
taking place. The above mentioned beverages shall be strictly confined to the
lounge area of the bowling alley. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.150: CARD AND GAME ROOMS INDIVIDUAL LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
It is unlawful for any person to keep, maintain or operate in the city any room
where there is played any bingo, backgammon, cards, checkers, or other games of
similar nature, or any game played with beans, buttons, dice or similar
devices, or to keep, maintain or operate in the city any table on which such
games are played, where a charge is made for the use of the room, use of the
tables, or for the privilege of playing on such tables or in such room, without
first obtaining a license. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.160: LICENSE APPLICATION; CONTENTS:
Applications shall be made to the license official and shall include a sworn
statement by the applicant showing the street and house number of the place
where it is proposed to maintain such room or table, the name of the place of
business and of any club, association or corporation operating the premises,
the number of tables used or intended to be used for playing games, and the
names and addresses of all officers of such organizations responsible for the
operation of the rooms or tables. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.170: INVESTIGATION BY THE POLICE DEPARTMENT:
The license official shall refer all applicants and sworn statements of
applicants to the police department office for an investigation and report. The
police department shall indicate the nature and kind of business conducted at
such place or at any other place by the applicant, and shall note whether
gambling of any description has been carried on or indulged in at the place,
whether known gamblers operate, supervise or play any game, or appear to be
employed in or about the card and game room, and whether the place is or has
been previously conducted in a lawful, orderly manner. The police department
shall make his recommendations as to the issuance or denial of the application.
(Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.180: CARD AND GAME ROOM FEE:
The annual license fee for conducting card and game rooms or tables for the
playing of cards shall be as specified on the fee schedule adopted pursuant to
section
5.06.040 of this title. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.190: PERIODIC INSPECTIONS:
The police department shall, after license has been issued, make periodic
inspections of the licensed premises in order to ensure strict compliance with
the provisions of this chapter and particularly with such as govern the
issuance of a license in the first instance. Violations shall be promptly
reported to the city, which shall take such action with regard to revocation as
it deems necessary. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.200: LICENSE REVOCATION:
The license of any person for the operation of card and game tables may be
revoked by the city at any time upon notice and hearing for the violation of
any ordinance of this city, or law of the state, or for any other good and
sufficient reason. Any decision under this section may be appealed as set forth
in chapter 5.11 of this title, as amended. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.210: CARD AND GAME ROOM HOURS OF OPERATION:
It is unlawful for any licensee or agent thereof to permit the use of card or
game rooms for the playing of games enumerated in this chapter between the
hours of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. of the same day.
(Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.220: UNOBSTRUCTED VIEW OF TABLES:
It is unlawful for any person to operate a card room where the view of the
tables from the entrance is blocked or obstructed by partitions or dividers of
any kind. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.230: LOCKED DOORS AND ALARM DEVICES PROHIBITED:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person licensed under the provisions of this
chapter to permit any game to be played behind locked, barred or barricaded
doors, or in such a place as is not readily accessible to law enforcement
officers.
   B.   No person shall keep upon such premises any lookout, signal, buzzer,
alarm or other device of any kind capable of use for the purpose of warning
occupants of the presence of law enforcement officers.
   C.   It is unlawful for any person to play any game behind a locked, barred
or barricaded door, or under any conditions hereinabove specified in this
chapter. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.240: ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to sell, dispense or allow to be consumed
alcoholic beverages on the premises of any card room. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.250: PLAYING FOR MONEY PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful to operate a business for profit to play cards and games for
money or anything of value, or to engage in any kind of gaming or gambling.
(Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.28.260: KNOWN GAMBLERS PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person licensed under the provisions of this chapter, or
the agent, manager or representative of such licensee, knowingly to employ any
known gambler, to conduct any of the games enumerated in this chapter, or to
work in or about licensed premises. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
CHAPTER 5.30
AUCTIONS
SECTION:
5.30.010: Definitions
5.30.020: Compliance With Chapter Requirements
5.30.030: Exemptions
5.30.040: Auctioneer's License Required
5.30.050: Fee
5.30.060: Record Keeping Requirements; Generally
5.30.070: By-Bidders Prohibited
5.30.080: False Representations Prohibited
5.30.010: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words shall have the following
meanings:
AUCTION HOUSE: A place of business where auctions are conducted and personal
property sold at auction.
AUCTIONEER: A person who conducts a public, competitive sale of property,
except a person selling his own property shall not for purposes of this chapter
be considered an "auctioneer", not the auctioneer's own, by outcry to the
highest bidder.
TRANSIENT AUCTION HOUSE: Any place, whether indoors or outdoors, located within
the city, where any goods, wares, merchandise or articles of value are offered
for sale at auction, and which is neither the permanent place of business for
auction sales nor a permanent business that has an auction sale to dispose of
its inventory, furnishings and business equipment as it goes out of business.
(Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.30.020: COMPLIANCE WITH CHAPTER REQUIREMENTS:
No personal property (goods, wares or merchandise) shall be sold at auction in
the city, except in compliance with this chapter. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.30.030: EXEMPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any auction held by any court
or officer thereof or any sheriff's sale, nor shall it apply to any auction
held for charitable or benevolent purposes or for any church, fair, festival,
nor to an auction wherein the general public is not invited nor permitted to
participate as bidders, and where the bidding is restricted to wholesalers or
retailers purchasing for resale. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.30.040: AUCTIONEER'S LICENSE REQUIRED:
It is unlawful to sell or cause to permit to be sold at auction any personal
property in the city unless such sale is conducted by an individual who has
applied for and obtained a temporary or regular business license from the city.
(Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.30.050: FEE:
The fee for a license shall be as specified on the fee schedule. (Ord. 05-14,
4-6-2005)
5.30.060: RECORD KEEPING REQUIREMENTS; GENERALLY:
In every case where an article is sold for seventy five dollars ($75.00) or
more, the licensee shall keep a complete record of all such sales made at an
auction, showing the name and address of each purchaser, a description of each
such article sold, including the number thereof and the date of each sale. The
record shall be open at all times for inspection by the license official or his
designee. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.30.070: BY-BIDDERS PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any person to act at any sale by auction as a by-bidder or
booster, to buy in behalf of the auctioneer or owner, or to increase the price
of the article to be sold, or to make any false bid. However, the owner may set
a minimum bid requirement. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.30.080: FALSE REPRESENTATIONS PROHIBITED:
It is unlawful for any auctioneer, when selling or offering for sale at public
auction any goods, wares or merchandise under the provisions of this chapter,
to describe the goods, wares or merchandise in any fraudulent, misleading,
untruthful or unwarranted manner tending to mislead bidders. It shall be
unlawful for any auctioneer or any person associated with him to substitute an
article sold for another. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
CHAPTER 5.34
FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS, NONCASH
(Rep. by Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
CHAPTER 5.36
FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS
SECTION:
5.36.010: Financial Institution Defined
5.36.020: License Required
5.36.030: Fee
5.36.040: Compliance With Statutes And Regulations
5.36.010: FINANCIAL INSTITUTION DEFINED:
"Financial institution" means any institution subject to the jurisdiction of
the Utah department of financial institutions or institutions subject to
jurisdiction or the equivalent of such department or another state or the
federal government. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.36.020: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It is unlawful for any person to operate or be engaged in the operation of a
financial institution in the city without first obtaining a license as required
in this chapter and registering with the Utah department of financial
institutions. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.36.030: FEE:
The annual license fee for a financial institution shall be as specified on the
fee schedule adopted pursuant to section
5.06.040 of this title. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
5.36.040: COMPLIANCE WITH STATUTES AND REGULATIONS:
Financial institutions shall comply with all other applicable state and federal
statutes, rules and regulations. (Ord. 10-01, 1-20-2010)
CHAPTER 5.38
CLUBS AND TEENAGE DANCE HALLS
SECTION:
5.38.010: Definitions
5.38.020: License Required
5.38.030: Exemptions
5.38.040: Issuance Conditions
5.38.050: Fee
5.38.060: Hours Of Operation
5.38.070: Supervision During Operation
5.38.080: Admittance; Age Restrictions
5.38.090: Proof Of Age To Be Shown
5.38.100: Pass-Out And Return Checks Prohibited
5.38.110: Lighting Of Premises And Parking Area
5.38.120: Unlawful Activities Designated
5.38.130: Alcoholic Beverages And Tobacco Prohibited
5.38.140: Access For Police Department Inspection
5.38.010: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter:
PUBLIC DANCE: Any dance to which the public generally may gain admission, with
or without the payment of a fee, but shall not include any dance conducted on
or in any public park, street or public grounds by permission of the city.
PUBLIC DANCE HALL: Any room, place or space in which a public dance is held or
in which classes in dancing are held and instruction in dancing is given for
hire.
PUBLIC TEENAGE DANCE HALL OR CLUB: Any room, house, building, structure or
place where dancing is permitted and public dancing is held, or in which
classes in dancing are held and instruction is given for hire and which is
designed or intended to attract or appeal to a teenage clientele, and to which
admittance may be gained by teenage persons, with or without payment or
admission.
An establishment will be regarded to be designed or intended to attract or
appeal to a teenage clientele when its name and decor, the type of music
provided, and the form and content of its advertising, together with any other
pertinent factors indicate such attraction or appeal is the intent or the
actual result thereof.
TEENAGE PERSON: Persons between the ages of thirteen (13) and nineteen (19),
inclusive. (Ord. 05-14, 4-6-2005)
5.38.020: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It is unlawful to operate a public teenage dance hall or club in the city
unless such hall or club is duly licensed as provided in this section. Any
establishment seeking to obtain or maintain a license under the provisions of
this chapter shall conform to all standards hereinafter enumerated. (Ord. 05-
14, 4-6-2005)
5.38.030: EXEMPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to dances, dance halls or clubs
conducted or sponsored by private or public schools, or by churches, for
