by written notice of the fire department's determination of responsibility and
the expenses to be recovered.
      2.   The notice shall specify that the determined responsible party may
appeal the fire department's decision.
   B.   In the event the determined responsible party appeals the
determination, a hearing officer shall hold a hearing to consider any issues
raised by the appeal, at which hearing the appealing party and the city shall
be entitled to present evidence in support of their respective positions. The
hearing officer shall be the mayor or a person appointed by the mayor with the
advice and consent of the city council.
   C.   After the hearing, the hearing officer, if appointed, shall make a
recommendation to the mayor, and the mayor shall issue a decision determining
responsibility and assessing expenses. The mayor may adopt, modify or remand
the recommendation of the hearing examiner, if appointed, for further
proceedings. (Ord. 04-11, 3-3-2004)
9.52.040: NO ADMISSION OF LIABILITY:
The payment of expenses determined owing under this chapter does not
constitute:
   A.   An admission of liability or negligence in any legal action for
damages; or
   B.   A criminal fine. (Ord. 04-11, 3-3-2004)
9.52.050: ACTION TO RECOVER EXPENSES:
In the event the parties determined to be responsible for the repayment of
expenses incurred due to the city's or the fire department's response to such
an emergency fail to make payment to the city within thirty (30) days after
issuance of the order or thirty (30) days from the deadline for appeal in the
event no appeal is filed, the city may initiate legal action to recover from
the determined responsible parties the expenses determined to be owing,
including the city's reasonable attorney fees. (Ord. 04-11, 3-3-2004)
CHAPTER 9.56
ADOPTION OF SALT LAKE VALLEY HEALTH DEPARTMENT REGULATIONS BY REFERENCE
SECTION:
9.56.010: Purpose
9.56.020: Regulations Adopted
9.56.030: Interpretation
9.56.040: Copies On File
9.56.010: PURPOSE:
The city council finds that it is in the best interest of the citizens of the
city to adopt the Salt Lake valley health department regulations to clarify the
authority of the city to enforce provisions of such regulations for violations
occurring within the city. (Ord. 04-11, 3-3-2004)
9.56.020: REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
The Salt Lake valley health department regulations, and amendments thereto, are
hereby adopted in their entirety. The regulations shall be construed to apply
only to the incorporated areas of the city and references in the regulations
including reference to personnel and officers of the Salt Lake valley health
department shall be interpreted and construed, where necessary to carry out the
intent of this chapter and title, to personnel and officers of the city. (Ord.
04-11, 3-3-2004)
9.56.030: INTERPRETATION:
In the event of any conflict between the provisions of the Salt Lake valley
health department regulations and the provisions of any other applicable
ordinance, statute, rule or regulation, the more restrictive provision shall
apply. (Ord. 04-11, 3-3-2004)
9.56.040: COPIES ON FILE:
Copies of the Salt Lake valley health department regulations shall be filed for
use and examination by the public in the offices of the city recorder. (Ord.
04-11, 3-3-2004)
CHAPTER 9.60
PENALTY FOR VIOLATION
SECTION:
9.60.010: Violation Penalty
9.60.010: VIOLATION PENALTY:
Any person who violates any provision or provisions of this title shall be
deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and punished by imprisonment in the county jail
not exceeding six (6) months, or by a fine in any sum less than one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00), or both, except that in all cases where a corporation is
convicted of an offense for the commission of which a natural person would be
punishable as for a misdemeanor, such corporation is punishable by a fine not
exceeding five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). (Ord. 04-11, 3-3-2004)
CHAPTER 9.61
PARKS
SECTION:
9.61.010: Definitions
9.61.020: Hours Of Use Of Off-Leash Park Areas
9.61.030: Off Leash Area Permit/Tag; Required For Use
9.61.040: Off Leash Area Permit/Tag; Term
9.61.050: Off Leash Area Permit/Tag; Revocation
9.61.060: Off Leash Area Permit/Tag; Requirements
9.61.070: Off Leash Area Permit/Tag; License Vendors
9.61.080: Hours Of Use Of Parks
9.61.090: Motor Vehicle Restriction
9.61.100: Skateboard And Scooter Restriction
9.61.110: Rules For Skateboard Park
9.61.120: Limit On Number Of Dogs
9.61.130: Business Restriction
9.61.140: Fire Making
9.61.150: Firearms And Explosives
9.61.160: Camping Restricted
9.61.170: Noise Restriction
9.61.180: Injuring Trees Or Other Improvements
9.61.190: Nuisance In Park
9.61.200: Rules For Off Leash Area
9.61.210: Enforcement Authority
9.61.220: Penalties
9.61.010: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms shall have the following meanings for purposes of this
chapter:
AUTHORIZED PERSON: A police officer, sheriff, deputy sheriff, emergency
services personnel, animal control officer, maintenance personnel, or
government employee or contractor on official business.
DIVISION AND DIRECTOR: Shall have the same meaning as those terms are defined
in title 8 of this code.
MOTOR VEHICLE: An automobile, truck, tote goat, motorcycle, motorbike,
snowmobile, low profile vehicle, motor assisted scooter, pocket bike,
minimotorcycle, go-cart, and any and all other self-propelled motor vehicles.
Motor vehicle does not include a vehicle designed for use by a person with a
disability.
OFF LEASH AREA: An enclosed, fenced parcel of real property located within a
park that has been set apart where dogs do not need to be under the immediate
physical control of their owners or persons charged with the care, custody, or
control of the dogs by means of a leash, tether, or other physical control
device.
PARKS OR PARK: A parcel of real property that is owned, leased, or controlled
by the city that has been set apart for the use of general public as a park,
whether developed or undeveloped.
SCOOTER: Any nonmotorized device consisting of two (2) or more wheels affixed
to a platform or footboard upon which the rider stands and which has a handle
or other mechanism at the front for holding or guiding the device. It also
includes every device generally recognized as a scooter but does not include a
bicycle.
SKATEBOARD: Any nonmotorized device consisting of two (2) or more wheels
affixed to a platform or footboard upon which a rider stands and which does not
have steering capabilities similar to that of a bicycle and does not have
brakes which operate on or upon the wheels of the skateboard and includes every
device generally recognized as a skateboard.
SKATEBOARD PARK: An enclosed, fenced parcel of real property that is located
within a park that has been set apart for skateboards.
UNAUTHORIZED PERSON: Any person who is not an authorized person. (Ord. 06-06,
2-15-2006)
9.61.020: HOURS OF USE OF OFF-LEASH PARK AREAS:
   A.   The hours of use of off-leash park areas shall be determined by the
city administration at its sole discretion. Hours of operation shall be posted
at each respective off-leash park area as soon as possible following the
administration’s determination of such hours.
   B.   It is unlawful for any unauthorized person to be in an off- leash park 
area, either on foot or in any type of motor vehicle or other conveyance,
during the hours that the off-leash park area is closed. (Ord. 09-29, 8-19-
2009; amd. Ord. 20-05, 2-5-2020)
9.61.030: OFF LEASH AREA PERMIT/TAG; REQUIRED FOR USE:
Any person harboring, exercising control, or having in his possession a dog in
the off leash area shall have an off leash area permit/tag for such dog. An off
leash area permit/tag may be obtained by submitting an application for an off
leash area permit/tag to the division, utilizing a standard form acceptable to
the division. The application shall be accompanied by evidence that is
acceptable to the director or his designee of a valid dog license issued by the
jurisdiction of the dog owner's residence and the prescribed off leash area
permit/tag fee as set forth in the fee schedule in title 8, chapter 8.99 of
this code. (Ord. 06-06, 2-15-2006)
9.61.040: OFF LEASH AREA PERMIT/TAG; TERM:
The off leash area permit/tag shall be issued for one year and be effective
from the date of purchase, through the end of the same month of the expiration
year as the month in which the off leash area permit/tag is purchased. (Ord.
06-06, 2-15-2006)
9.61.050: OFF LEASH AREA PERMIT/TAG; REVOCATION:
If the owner of any dog(s) is found to be in violation of this chapter or of
title 8 of this code on three (3) or more different occasions, within a twenty
four (24) month period, the director may seek a court order pursuant to title
8, chapter 8.40 of this code, revoking for a period of one year any off leash
area permit(s)/tag(s) such person may possess. Persons seeking reapplication of
said off leash area permit/tag must comply with conditions as set forth by the
director that may include, but not be limited to, sterilization of the dog.
(Ord. 06-06, 2-15-2006)
9.61.060: OFF LEASH AREA PERMIT/TAG; REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Upon satisfying the requirements of section
9.61.030 of this chapter, the director or designee shall issue to the owner a
receipt and an off leash area permit/tag in the form of a tag for each dog
permitted. The off leash area permit/tag shall have stamped thereon the off
leash area permit/tag number, corresponding with off leash area permit/tag
number on the receipt. The owner shall attach the off leash area permit/tag to
the collar or harness of the dog and see that the dog constantly wears the
collar and off leash area permit/tag while in the off leash area. Failure to
attach the off leash area permit/tag as provided shall be a violation of this
chapter.
   B.   Off leash area permit/tags are not transferable from one dog to another
or from one owner to another. No refunds shall be made on any off leash area
permit/tag for any reason whatsoever. Replacement for lost or destroyed off
leash area permit/tags shall be allowed upon payment to the division of the
replacement off leash area permit/tag fee set forth in the fee schedule of
title 8, chapter 8.99 of this code. (Ord. 06-06, 2-15-2006)
9.61.070: OFF LEASH AREA PERMIT/TAG; LICENSE VENDORS:
The director may contract with veterinary hospitals, veterinarians, pet shops,
animal grooming parlors, and similar institutions or individuals for the
issuance of off leash area permit/tag application forms. (Ord. 06-06, 2-15-
2006)
9.61.080: HOURS OF USE OF PARKS:
The hours and days that a park is open and closed are as follows:
   A.   Parks shall be closed beginning November 1 through March 31 from eight
o'clock (8:00) P.M. until seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. of the next day and shall
be open from seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. until eight o'clock (8:00) P.M.
   B.   Parks shall be closed beginning April 1 through October 31 from ten
o'clock (10:00) P.M. until seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. of the next day and shall
be open from seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. until ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
It is unlawful for any unauthorized person to be in a park, either on foot or
in any type of motor vehicle or other conveyance, during the hours that a park
is closed. (Ord. 09-29, 8-19-2009)
9.61.090: MOTOR VEHICLE RESTRICTION:
   A.   It is unlawful to operate or drive any motor vehicle within any park at
a speed in excess of that speed posted on a particular road, trail, or pathway
within the park.
   B.   It is unlawful to operate or drive a motor vehicle within a park other
than in those areas specifically designated and posted for that particular use.
This prohibition shall not apply, however, to motorized or self-propelled
equipment used within the park by authorized personnel for transportation or
that is used for maintenance and service of park facilities. Emergency vehicles
are also exempt from this provision. (Ord. 06-06, 2-15-2006)
9.61.100: SKATEBOARD AND SCOOTER RESTRICTION:
   A.   Every person riding a skateboard or scooter shall exercise due care and
reasonable caution to prevent injuries to others, to himself, or to property.
   B.   Every person riding a skateboard or scooter shall yield the right of
way to pedestrians at all times.
   C.   Skateboards and scooters shall not be ridden upon any stairway, wall,
bench, parking lot, roadway, or on or over any landscaped area, including, but
not limited to, grass areas, shrubbery, or flowerbeds located in a park. (Ord.
06-06, 2-15-2006)
9.61.110: RULES FOR SKATEBOARD PARK:
   A.   The rules for the skateboard park are set forth below:
      1.   The skateboard park is open thirty (30) minutes before sunrise and
is closed thirty (30) minutes after sunset.
      2.   Users of the skateboard park must utilize appropriate safety
equipment, including helmets and pads.
      3.   No food or drink or glass containers are allowed in the skateboard
park.
      4.   No alcohol, drug, and tobacco products are allowed in the skateboard
park.
      5.   Use of the skateboard park is at your own risk.
   B.   The rules shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the skateboard park
and shall include the following disclaimer:
Skating/skateboarding/rollerblading is an inherently- dangerous sport. The
dangers of skating/skateboarding/rollerblading include, but are not limited to,
injury or death resulting from changing track conditions arising from changing
weather conditions; variations in or steepness of skating area, rain, snow, or
ice conditions; surface conditions, such as the introduction of debris onto the
course; collision with other skaters, and the skater's failure to skate or
behave in a safe and reasonable manner. Utilizing this facility constitutes
your acceptance of the above cited rules, the above cited risks, and your
willingness to assume personal responsibility for any and all injuries arising
from the use of this facility. If you are unwilling to obey these rules or
assume these risks, for yourself, or for those under your supervision, you
should not use this facility.
   C.   It is unlawful to violate the rules for the Skateboard Park. (Ord. 06-
06, 2-15-2006)
9.61.120: LIMIT ON NUMBER OF DOGS:
It is unlawful for any person at any one time to harbor, exercise control, or
have in his possession more dogs in the off leash area than permitted in
section
9.61.200 of this chapter. (Ord. 06-06, 2-15-2006)
9.61.130: BUSINESS RESTRICTION:
Except as specifically authorized by the City, it is unlawful for any person to
sell or display for sale any merchandise or goods, products, or operate a
business, including temporary food vendor cart, in a park. (Ord. 06-06, 2-15-
2006)
9.61.140: FIRE MAKING:
It is unlawful for any person to make or kindle a fire within a park for any
reason unless such person uses a designated area which has a fireplace,
barbecue grill, or other facility designated by the City to contain a fire.
(Ord. 06-06, 2-15-2006)
9.61.150: FIREARMS AND EXPLOSIVES:
It is unlawful for any unauthorized person to discharge any firearm,
firecracker, rocket, torpedo, powder, or any other fireworks or explosives
within a park. (Ord. 06-06, 2-15-2006)
9.61.160: CAMPING RESTRICTED:
It is unlawful for any person to camp or lodge in a park, unless otherwise
permitted by the City. (Ord. 17-21, 10-18-2017)
9.61.170: NOISE RESTRICTION:
It is unlawful for any person to play or cause to be played amplified sound or
music in a park without a permit from the City. Such permit may be denied where
it is the reasonable belief of the City that such sound or music would have a
propensity to disturb the peaceful enjoyment of the park by other members of
the public or annoy residents neighboring the park. It shall be the
responsibility of any person obtaining such permit to ensure that the permit is
available for inspection by authorized personnel. The issuance of any permit
does not exempt the holder thereof from applicable rules and regulations
regarding noise emissions. (Ord. 06-06, 2-15-2006)
9.61.180: INJURING TREES OR OTHER IMPROVEMENTS:
It is unlawful for any person to move any building or other object so as to
injure or interfere with any tree, shrub, statue, monument, or other
improvements standing in any street or park or scratch, cut, mark, or deface
any tree, shrub, statue, monument, or other improvements in any street or park.
(Ord. 06-06, 2-15-2006)
9.61.190: NUISANCE IN PARK:
It is unlawful for any person or persons to scratch, cut, injure, or deface any
building, fence, structure, or other property or foul any fountains or any
other improvements, or to cut or injure flowers or flowerbeds within the park.
(Ord. 06-06, 2-15-2006)
9.61.200: RULES FOR OFF LEASH AREA:
   A.   The rules for the off leash area are set forth below:
      1.   All dogs must be on a leash except in the off leash area.
      2.   All dogs using the off leash area must be wearing a current license
tag and off leash area permit/tag and be current on all required immunizations
unless exempt by title 8 of this Code.
      3.   Dog defecation must be immediately cleaned up by the person
handling, harboring, exercising control or possession of such dog, and the
defecation must be placed in a proper trash receptacle.
      4.   Aggressive dogs and dog owners are prohibited from the off leash
area.
      5.   Dogs in the off leash area must be under the supervision of a person
over the age of twelve (12).
      6.   Female dogs in heat and dogs under the age of four (4) months are
not allowed in the off leash area. No animals except canines are allowed in the
off leash area.
      7.   Persons handling, harboring, exercising control or possession of
dogs are required to quiet their barking dogs or remove them from the park area
and are also required to stop dogs from digging and must repair all damage that
occurs.
      8.   No food (human or animal) is allowed in the off leash area.
      9.   Dogs are not allowed in the tot lot area.
      10.   The off leash area hours shall be as stated in section
9.61.020 of this chapter.
      11.   Violators of these rules shall be punished as set forth in section
9.61.220 of this chapter.
      12.   It is unlawful for any person at any one time to harbor, exercise
control, or have in his possession more than two (2) dogs in the off leash
area.
   B.   The rules shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the off leash area
and shall include the following disclaimer:
Any person who brings a dog into the off-leash area assumes the legal
responsibility for any damage, disease, or injury to persons, other dogs, or
property caused by the dog. Utilizing this off-leash area constitutes your
acceptance of the above cited rules, and your willingness to assume personal
responsibility for any and all injuries arising from the use of the off-leash
area. If you are unwilling to obey these rules or assume these risks, for
yourself, or for those under your supervision, you should not use the off-
leash area.
(Ord. 09-36, 11-4-2009)
9.61.210: ENFORCEMENT AUTHORITY:
The city's designated animal control service contract provider, other agent
designated by the city, or any law enforcement officer is hereby authorized and
empowered to enforce the provisions of this chapter and to apprehend, to
transport, and impound any animals found in violation of this chapter, or any
licensed or unlicensed animal for any other violation of title 8 of this code,
and to issue criminal citations. (Ord. 06-06, 2-15-2006)
9.61.220: PENALTIES:
Violation of this chapter shall be an infraction. The schedule of penalties for
violation of this chapter is:
   A.   Fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first offense, one hundred dollars
($100.00) for the second and subsequent offenses.
   B.   When determining under this section if an offense is a second or
subsequent offense, only prior convictions committed within the twenty four
(24) months prior to the commission of the current offense may be considered.
(Ord. 06-06, 2-15-2006)
CHAPTER 9.65
SMOKING PROHIBITED IN CITY PARKS, TRAILS, AND RECREATION FACILITIES
SECTION:
9.65.010: Purpose
9.65.020: Definitions
9.65.030: Smoking Prohibited
9.65.040: Smoking In Designated Areas (Rep. by Ord. 18-19, 5-16-2018)
9.65.045: Posting Of Signs
9.65.050: Penalties
9.65.010: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to protect the health, safety, and welfare of
the public by prohibiting smoking in City parks, recreation areas and
facilities, and trails. (Ord. 12-01, 1-4-2012)
9.65.020: DEFINITIONS:
CITY OWNED PARKS, TRAILS, AND RECREATION FACILITIES: All City owned parks,
trails, trailheads, and recreation facilities, including parking lots for such
facilities.
SMOKING: Smoking means:
   A.   The possession of any lighted or heated tobacco product in any form;
   B.   Inhaling, exhaling, burning, or carrying any lighted or heated cigar,
cigarette, pipe, or hookah that contains:
      1.   Tobacco or any plant product intended for inhalation;
      2.   Shisha or non-tobacco shisha;
      3.   Nicotine;
      4.   A natural or synthetic tobacco substitute; or
      5.   A natural or synthetic flavored tobacco product;
   C.   Using an oral smoking device intended to circumvent the prohibition of
smoking in this chapter. (Ord. 18-19, 5-16-2018)
9.65.030: SMOKING PROHIBITED:
Smoking is prohibited in City owned parks, trails, and recreation facilities,
including parking lots for such facilities. (Ord. 18-19, 5-16-2018)
9.65.040: SMOKING IN DESIGNATED AREAS:
(Rep. by Ord. 18-19, 5-16-2018)
9.65.045: POSTING OF SIGNS:
"No Smoking" signs shall be clearly and conspicuously posted in City owned
parks, trails, and recreational facilities and parking lots of City owned
parks, trails, and recreational facilities. (Ord. 18-19, 5-16-2018)
9.65.050: PENALTIES:

C misdemeanor for each subsequent offense. (Ord. 12-01, 1-4-2012)

CHAPTER 10.10
GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
10.10.010: Criminal Code Adopted
10.10.020: Controlled Substances Act Adopted
10.10.030: Alcoholic Beverage Control Act Adopted
10.10.040: Severability
10.10.010: CRIMINAL CODE ADOPTED:
   A.   Chapters 1 through 4 of title 76 of the Utah Code Annotated are adopted
by reference in their entirety;
   B.   Chapters 5 through 10 of title 76 of the Utah Code Annotated are
adopted by reference to the extent that those chapters describe criminal
violations which are classified therein as either an infraction, class C
misdemeanor, or class B misdemeanor, and the classifications of offenses and
the penalties prescribed for those violations as provided by state law are
adopted by reference;
   C.   Nothing in this section shall be construed to affect or amend in any
way the provisions of ordinances 93-42 and 93-44 relating to the sale to and
possession of certain firearms by minors and the five (5) day review
requirement for the purchase of a firearm in the city. (Ord. 05-25, 5-18-2005)
10.10.020: CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES ACT ADOPTED:
Chapters 37, 37a, 37b, and 37c of title 58 of the Utah Code Annotated,
pertaining generally to controlled substances, are adopted by reference to the
extent that those chapters describe criminal violations which are classified as
either an infraction, class C misdemeanor, class B misdemeanor, and the
classifications of offenses and the penalties prescribed for those violations
as provided by state law are adopted by reference. (Ord. 05-25, 5-18-2005)
10.10.030: ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE CONTROL ACT ADOPTED:
Chapter 12 of title 32A of the Utah Code Annotated is adopted by reference to
the extent that the chapter describes criminal violations which are classified
as either an infraction, class C misdemeanor, class B misdemeanor, and the
classifications of offenses and the penalties prescribed for those violations
as provided by state law are adopted by reference. (Ord. 05-25, 5-18-2005)
10.10.040: SEVERABILITY:
In the event that any provision of this title is deemed invalid for any reason,
the remaining provisions shall remain in full force and effect. (Ord. 05-25, 5-
18-2005)
CHAPTER 10.20
OFFENSES BY OR AGAINST MINORS
SECTION:
10.20.010: Definitions
10.20.020: Unlawful To Distribute Or Furnish Sex Paraphernalia To Minors
10.20.010: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings as
defined in this section:
DISPLAY PUBLICLY: The exposing, placing, posting, exhibiting, or in any fashion
displaying in any location, whether public or private, an item in a manner that
it may be readily seen, and its content or character distinguished by normal
unaided vision viewing it from a public thoroughfare, place or vehicle.
DISTRIBUTE: To transfer possession of, with or without consideration.
KNOWINGLY: To have actual or constructive knowledge of the contents of the
subject matter. A person has "constructive knowledge" if a reasonable
inspection under the circumstances would have disclosed the nature of the
subject matter or if the failure to inspect is for the purpose of avoiding such
disclosure.
MINOR: Any unmarried person less than eighteen (18) years of age.
PERSON: Shall not be limited to individuals only but shall include public and
private corporations, firms, joint associations, partnerships and the like. The
word "person" as used in this chapter, shall apply to a natural person and
shall apply equally to the male and female genders.
PROMOTE: To manufacture, issue, transmit, publish, circulate, disseminate,
present, exhibit, or advertise, or to offer or agree to do the same.
SEX PARAPHERNALIA: Any item, device or product, other than a "sexual device",
as defined in this section, which is manufactured, promoted or designed to be
used primarily for sexual stimulation, sexual arousal, or the enhancing or
prolonging of sexual activity. "Sex paraphernalia" shall not mean any device,
appliance or pill designed to be used primarily for contraception purposes and
shall not mean movies, books, magazines, or other communicative materials
protected by the first amendment of the United States constitution.
SEXUAL DEVICE: Any item, device or product, including, but not limited to, a
dildo, vibrator, artificial vagina, Spanish fly, benwa balls, pillows or other
products shaped or made to resemble male or female genitals, buttocks, or
developed female breasts, edible underwear, flavored or unflavored edible body
lotion or other substance designed for internal consumption, or any other item,
device or product manufactured, promoted or designed to be used primarily for
sexual stimulation, sexual arousal, or the enhancing or prolonging of sexual
activity.
WILFULLY: A purpose or willingness to commit the act or to omit an act required
herein. (Ord. 05-25, 5-18-2005)
10.20.020: UNLAWFUL TO DISTRIBUTE OR FURNISH SEX PARAPHERNALIA TO MINORS:
It is unlawful for any person to knowingly and wilfully distribute or furnish
any sex paraphernalia to any minor. Each distribution to a minor shall
constitute a separate offense. A violation of this section is a class B
misdemeanor. (Ord. 05-25, 5-18-2005)
CHAPTER 10.30
DISORDERLY CONDUCT
SECTION:
10.30.010: Loitering
10.30.020: Camping And Sleeping On Public Grounds
10.30.030: Placing Printed Material On Vehicles
10.30.010: LOITERING:
   A.   A person is guilty of loitering if such person:
      1.   Appears at a place or at a time under circumstances that warrant
alarm for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity, and upon inquiry
by a law enforcement official, such person fails to give a reasonably credible
account of his identity, conduct, or purposes; or
      2.   Loiters, remains, wanders, or lingers idly in or about a school,
either by walking, sitting, standing, or by sitting in or upon a vehicle or
conveyance, not having any reason or relationship involving custody of or
responsibility for a pupil or student or any other specific, legitimate reason
for being there, and not having written permission from anyone authorized to
grant the same, and upon inquiry of a law enforcement official, such person
fails to give a reasonably credible account of his identity, conduct or
purposes; or
      3.   Loiters, remains, wanders or lingers idly in or about a building,
lot, street, sidewalk or any other public or private place, either by walking,
sitting, standing, or by sitting in or upon a vehicle or conveyance, without
apparent reason and under circumstances which justify suspicion that he may be
engaged in or about to engage in a crime, and upon inquiry of a law enforcement
official, such person fails to give a reasonably credible account of his
identity, conduct or purposes; or
      4.   Is on or in any public area as hereafter defined, and which person:
         a.   Remains, wanders idly or prowls:
            (1)   In a manner or at a time not usual for law abiding citizens;
or
            (2)   Under circumstances that warrant a reasonable alarm or
immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity; or
            (3)   Accosts other persons in any public place or in any place
open to the public for the purpose of begging; and
         b.   Refuses to obey the lawful command of a law enforcement officer
to move on, or provide to said police officer a lawful reason for remaining on
or in said public area as hereafter defined;
         c.   The law enforcement officer's command shall be lawfully given
when the alleged loitering by such person creates or causes to be created:
            (1)   A breach of the peace; or
            (2)   The actual or attempted obstruction, molestation or
interference of any other person lawfully on or in any "public area", as
hereafter defined, in such a manner as to cause such other person to reasonably
fear for his safety; or
            (3)   The obstruction or attempted obstruction of the free normal
flow of vehicular traffic, or the normal passage of pedestrian traffic in said
public areas; or
            (4)   The unreasonable disturbance of any person acting lawfully on
or in any said public place;
         d.   For the purposes of this subsection, "public area" means any
place open to the public, including, but not limited to, any common public area
of any shopping mall, public way, street, highway, alley or park.
   B.   No person shall be convicted under this section if the explanation such
person gave of his conduct and purposes was true and, if believed by the law
enforcement official at the time, would have dispelled the alarm.
   C.   Loitering is a class C misdemeanor. (Ord. 05-25, 5-18-2005)
10.30.020: CAMPING AND SLEEPING ON PUBLIC GROUNDS:
   A.   It is unlawful for any person, and such person shall be guilty of a
class C misdemeanor for each day of violation hereof, to camp, lodge, cook,
make a fire or pitch a tent, fly, lean-to, tarpaulin, umbrella or any other
type of ground cover or shelter, or place sleeping bags, bedding or any other
type of camping or sleeping equipment on any "public grounds", as defined in
subsection B of this section, and it is unlawful for any person, and such
person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor for each day of violation hereof, to
use or benefit from the use of any of the foregoing items of shelter or camping
or sleeping equipment to fail to remove the same from such public grounds
within a reasonable amount of time after being requested to do so by any law
enforcement officer or citizen.
   B.   For the purpose of this section, the term "public grounds" means any
real property owned in whole or in part by the United States of America and its
agencies, or the state of Utah or any of its political subdivisions, upon which
camping or sleeping has not been authorized by the owner. (Ord. 05-25, 5-18-
2005)
10.30.030: PLACING PRINTED MATERIAL ON VEHICLES:
It is unlawful for any person, and such person shall be guilty of a class C
misdemeanor for each day of violation hereof, to distribute, deposit, place,
throw, scatter or cast, or cause to be distributed, deposited, placed, thrown,
scattered or cast, any handbill, circular, card, booklet, placard or other
printed or written commercial advertisement, except notice of parking
violations in or upon any automobile or other vehicle. (Ord. 05-25, 5-18-2005)
CHAPTER 10.40
TRESPASS
SECTION:
10.40.010: Trespass On City Property
10.40.020: Trespass From A Public Recreational Trail
10.40.010: TRESPASS ON CITY PROPERTY:
It is unlawful for any person, and such person shall be guilty of a class C
misdemeanor for each day of violation hereof, to drive or operate any self-
propelled motor vehicle in, on or about any property belonging to the city, or
under the control of the city, except on public highways, streets and roads,
unless such property is specifically designated and posted for such use. (Ord.
05-25, 5-18-2005)
10.40.020: TRESPASS FROM A PUBLIC RECREATIONAL TRAIL:
It is unlawful for any person, and such person shall be guilty of a class C
misdemeanor for each day of violation hereof, for the purpose of biking,
hiking, or any other activity to wilfully leave the boundaries of any public
recreational trail across privately owned lands without the express consent of
the landowner whenever notice against leaving the trail has been given by
posting of a sign or signs reasonably likely to notify trail users. (Ord. 05-
25, 5-18-2005)
CHAPTER 10.50
CURFEW
SECTION:
10.50.010: Definitions
10.50.020: Curfew If Under Age Sixteen
10.50.030: Curfew If Age Sixteen Or Seventeen
10.50.040: Parental Liability
10.50.050: Business Liability
10.50.060: Exceptions
10.50.070: Enforcement
10.50.010: DEFINITIONS:
CARE AND CUSTODY: The legal authority of a parent or guardian to supervise or
otherwise be responsible for a minor, or the express authority given from such
parent or legal guardian of a minor to a responsible adult to supervise or
otherwise be responsible for the activities and care of the minor.
EMERGENCY ERRAND: Any errand or travel undertaken to directly and immediately
seek to prevent or reduce the consequences of an illness or injury, criminal or
potentially criminal activity, or fire or other accident and shall include the
seeking of aid and assistance from medical or emergency response personnel or
the purchase of medications.
MINOR: Any unmarried, unemancipated person who is not a member of the armed
forces of the United States and who is under the age of sixteen (16) years for
the purposes of section
10.50.020 of this chapter or who is age sixteen (16) years or seventeen (17)
years for the purposes of section
10.50.030 of this chapter.
PUBLIC PLACES: Any place open to the public, whether publicly or privately
owned, including, but not limited to, parking lots and the interiors and
exteriors of commercial establishments such as restaurants, stores or places of
entertainment. (Ord. 05-25, 5-18-2005)
10.50.020: CURFEW IF UNDER AGE SIXTEEN:
It is unlawful for any minor under the age of sixteen (16) years to remain or
loiter upon any of the sidewalks, streets, alleys or public places in the city,
between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. and five o'clock (5:00) A.M.
the following morning. (Ord. 05-25, 5-18-2005)
10.50.030: CURFEW IF AGE SIXTEEN OR SEVENTEEN:
It is unlawful for any minor who is age sixteen (16) years or seventeen (17) to
remain or loiter upon any of the sidewalks, streets, alleys or public places in
the city, between the hours of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and five o'clock (5:00)
A.M. (Ord. 05-25, 5-18-2005)
10.50.040: PARENTAL LIABILITY:
It is unlawful for any parent, guardian or other person having care and custody
of any minor to allow or permit the minor to violate the provisions of this
chapter. Violation is a misdemeanor. (Ord. 05-25, 5-18-2005)
10.50.050: BUSINESS LIABILITY:
No person owning or operating a business as defined by this code shall
knowingly permit any minor to remain on the premises of such business in
violation of the provisions of this section. Any such violation shall be a
misdemeanor. This section, however, shall not apply to any minor who is
lawfully employed on the premises. (Ord. 05-25, 5-18-2005)
10.50.060: EXCEPTIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any circumstances in which
the minor is:
   A.   Accompanied by a parent, guardian or other responsible adult having
care and custody of such minor;
   B.   Engaged in legitimate trade, employment or occupation which requires
the minor's presence in or on the sidewalks, streets, alleys or public places
while working at or traveling to or from such employment;
   C.   Engaged in an emergency errand directed by the minor's parent, guardian
or other responsible person having care and custody;
   D.   In a motor vehicle engaged in a normal interstate travel beginning in,
traveling through, or ending in the city;
   E.   Attending or engaged in traveling between the minor's home or place of
residence and a place where any religious, municipal, social, entertainment,
sporting, political, library or school function is occurring; or
   F.   Within the immediate vicinity of the minor's place of residence. (Ord.
05-25, 5-18-2005)
10.50.070: ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   Any minor who is in violation of the provisions of this chapter is
subject to arrest and citation.
   B.   Upon arrest, the minor shall be returned to the custody of the parent,
guardian or other person charged with the care and custody of the minor.
   C.   It is unlawful for any parent, guardian or other person charged with
the care and custody of a minor who is in violation of this chapter to refuse
to appear and take custody of the minor within a reasonable time after being
ordered to do so by a peace officer.
   D.   Any violation of this chapter is a misdemeanor. (Ord. 05-25, 5-18-2005)
CHAPTER 10.60
FIREARMS AND WEAPONS
SECTION:
10.60.010: Discharge Prohibited Within City Limits; Exceptions
10.60.010: DISCHARGE PROHIBITED WITHIN CITY LIMITS; EXCEPTIONS:
It is unlawful to discharge any firearm within the city limits except in self-
defense, or defense of property, or in the case of any peace officer, in the
performance of his duty, or at a duly licensed shooting gallery or range. (Ord.
05-25, 5-18-2005)

2006)   11.28
